courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Principles of Environmental and Occupational Health
courses.description: This public health oriented course addresses how the environmental and occupational (work-related) factors affect human health and what we can do to prevent or minimize the negative impacts. Whereas environmental science tends to address how human beings affect the environment, this course focuses on how the environment affects human health. Topics include an introduction to major categories of environmental hazards that impact population health; environmental epidemiology methods in assessing the impact of environmental exposures on human health; the evaluation and control of common hazards in the work place; and the impacts of global environmental changes on health.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PHPC2009.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Discuss the history and definition of environmental and occupational health
2. Describe epidemiology and risk analysis methods to evaluate the impact of environmental exposures on human health
3. Define the major categories of hazards in the environment and workplaces
4. Discuss the direct and indirect human health effects of major environmental and occupational agents
5. Discuss the general principles of environmental pollution mitigation and occupational hazard control
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Exposure, dose and risk analysis
3. Fundamentals of environmental epidemiology
4. Environmental hazard and health impact
5. Natural environment and health
6. Work and health
7. Occupational disease and injury; Occupational legislation
8. Environmental health problems in Hong Kong
9. Environmental health for all: global issues and international treaties
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted in mid-term and at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings: Essentials of environmental health. Robert H. Friis.Sudbury, Mass. : Jones and Bartlett, c2007.

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Hong Kong Health Care System
courses.description: Healthcare systems are complex and multidisciplinary in nature. They need to meet population needs and may include a network of services such as prevention, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and health maintenance provided to individuals of all ages and with a range of needs. This course is an introductory course on basic definitions and functions of health care systems. Using case studies and discussions, students will be able to develop understanding of practice and resources in health care.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
• Understand how health and social care are interrelated and delivered
• Understand the basic concepts and functions of health and care systems for primary, secondary and tertiary care
• Gain a brief overview of different healthcare systems from local and global perspectives
• Gain a brief understanding of role of financing, hospital organization, management, and different parties involvement in healthcare system
courses.course_syllabus:
| 1. Introduction and Overview 2. Community Care I 3. Community Care II 4. Primary Care 5. Acute Hospital Care I 6. Acute Hospital Care II 7. Community-based rehabilitation 8. Long-term care |
| --- |
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings:
1. Robin Gauld & Derek Gould. (2002). The Hong Kong health sector: Development & change

2. Leung G.M. & Bacon-Shone J. (2006). Hong Kong's health system: reflections, perspectives and visions.

3. Allot M. & Robb M. (1998). Understanding health & social care: an introductory reader. London: Sage in association with the Open University

4. Carrin G. et al (2009). Health systems policy, finance, and organization. USA: Academic Press.

5. Smith R.D. & Hanson K. (2012). Health systems in low-and middle-income countries: An economic & policy perspective. New York: Oxford University Press Inc

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Contemporary Health Issues
courses.description: We are living in a highly complex and interdependent world. Health of the population is not only affected by local environment and individual behavioral choices, but also by other factors that are of regional and international origin. This course will introduce various major contemporary health issues that are threatening the health of people around the world, and the strategies that are being used to tackle these issues.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course introduction

2. Noncommunicable diseases

3. Weak primary health care

4. Fragile and vulnerable settings

5. Air pollution and climate change

6. Climate change challenges

7. Dengue

8. HIV, Ebola and other high-threat pathogens

9. Global influenza pandemic and COVID-19

10. Antimicrobial resistance & Vaccine hesitancy

11. Sustainable Development and Health
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in the form of close-ended and open-ended questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course website.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by the course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Health Education and Health Behaviours
courses.description: The objectives of this module are teaching students the concept of health in relation to health education and health promotion in community. Different behavioral theories, models and approaches will be explored. This module will also look into how health promotion practice links to different models of health behaviours . Through understanding of factors related to health behaviour, modifications for healthy lifestyle can be planned within the social and cultural context. Students will learn how to put theory into practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PHPC2016
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Acquire knowledge on the most common theories, models, and approaches used in studying health-related behaviours
2. Apply the theories into promoting health-related behaviours with the respective groups
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Scope of health behavior and health education, Theory, research and practice in health behaviour and health education

2. Self-Determination Theory

3. The Transtheoretical Model

4. The Theory of Planned Behavior and the Integrated Behavioral Model

5. The Fear Appeal approach, the Extended Parallel Process Model and The Health Belief Model

6. Elaboration likelihood model of persuasion

7. The Social Cognitive Theory

8. Social network and Social support

9. Stress, coping, and health behavior

10. Ecological models of health behaviour

11. Diffusion of Innovations, Course review
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.

courses.recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706

Students will apply the models to assess and report the health needs of a community through both primary and secondary data collection and analysis.

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Biostatistics for Community Health
courses.description: This course will introduce the basic biostatistics concepts for public health practice. Emphasis will be placed on conceptual understanding of statistical approaches to public health data rather than on theory and equations. To enable students to acquire a set of analytical skills to deal with various public health questions, the course will focus on analyzing common types of public health data, and introduce exploratory and confirmatory biostatistical methods. The biostatistics concepts will be taught together with a user-friendly software SPSS through detailed, illustrative examples.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken COMM3110, DSME2010, 2020, 2011, 2021, ECON2121, GRMD2102, PHPC1015, PHPC2015, PSYC2010, SEEM2430, SPED2600, STAT2101, 2102, 2001 or 2006.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student should be able to:
1. Apply the fundamental knowledge and skills of biostatistics for community health practice.
2. Critically evaluate a study design and statistical reporting in respect of biostatistics.
3. Interpret common statistics used in tables and figures of health-related research and reports.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to biostatistics for public health practice
2. Descriptive statistics: Levels of measurement, measuring central tendency and variability, frequency tables, and statistical figures
3. Probability
4. Distributions of data
5. Sampling distributions
6. Estimation
7. Hypothesis testing for continuous data
8. Hypothesis testing for categorical data
9. Nonparametric tests
10. Measuring associations: correlation and simple linear regression
11. Measuring associations for multiple variables: Multiple linear regression I
12. Measuring associations for multiple variables: Multiple linear regression II
13. Practical data analysis/ Interpretation of statistical results
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by the course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Gerstman BB. Basic biostatistics. Jones & Bartlett Learning, LLC; 2014.
2. Statistics Notes in the British Medical Journal, free downloads at: http://www-users.york.ac.uk/~mb55/pubs/pbstnote.htm

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Epidemiology for Community Health
courses.description: This course aims to provide a basic understanding of the fundamental principles of epidemiological methods and their applicability to the field of health research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PHPC1014 or PHPC2017
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to:
1. Demonstrate basic theoretical knowledge of epidemiology.
2. Use a wide range of epidemiological skills in support of established practices in community health.
3. Apply knowledge and skills in planning and design of projects to improve community health.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to epidemiology; common sources of health data & introduction to research ethics
2. Measures of disease occurrence; adjustment of rates
3. Descriptive studies & cross-sectional studies
4. Sampling methods
5. Cohort studies
6. Case-control Studies
7. Confounding
8. Intervention studies
9. Data collection methods
10. Effect modification, bias, and causal inference in epidemiology
11. Principles of screening
12. Brief overview of systematic reviews
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings: 1. Epidemiology for the Unitiated. D. Coggon,Geoffrey Rose,DJP Barker. (2003) BMJ publishers.
courses.recommended_readings:
2. Epidemiology and Public Health Medicine (by Normal Vetter) Published by Elsevier Publishing.
3. Medical statistics made easy / Michael Harris and Gordon Taylor. London ; New York : Martin Dunitz ; Independence, KY : Distributed in the USA by Taylor & Francis, 2004.

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Settings-Approach for Health Promotion
courses.description: Community health intervention is putting more emphasis on modification of health risk behaviours and building up the personal, cognitive and social skills which determine the ability of the individuals to gain access to, understand and make use of the information to promote and maintain good health. In many countries, there is a well-structured health care system to address diseases and illnesses but there is no system addressing health particularly on promotion of positive health. Healthy Setting is a value-based approach which has the ability of translation into language to fit the context of the particular setting. The concept of Healthy Setting is evolution from Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion by building healthy public policy, re-orientation of health services, strengthening community actions, building up personal health skills and health advocacy. This module will discuss the role of different settings in promoting health of the population. Students will gain basic understanding of healthy cities, health promoting school, health promoting workplace and other common settings.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introduction to Settings Approach for Health Promotion (I); Introduction of Course Project
2. Introduction to Settings-Approach for Health Promotion (II); Course project topic brainstorming

3. Needs Assessment in Healthy Settings; Workshop: Project Planning (Elements of Needs Assessment in Health Promotion in Schools)

4. Programme Planning and Evaluation in Health Settings; Workshop: Project Planning (Design of Evaluation Indicators in Health Promotion in School)

5. Schools as Health Settings

6. Conducting Needs Assessment for Course Project

7. Health Promotion in Health Care Organisations; Progress Presentation of Group Project

8. Health Promoting Workplace

9. Concept of the Healthy Cities

10. Health Promotion in Other Settings

11. Visiting Health Promotion in Settings

12. Course round up

13. Final Presentation of Group Project
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings:
1. Poland, BD, Green, LW, Rootman, I, editors. (2000). Settings for health promotion: Linking theory and practice. Sage Publications, Inc.

2. Dooris, M. (2009). Holistic and sustainable health improvement: the contribution of the settings-based approach to health promotion. Perspectives in Public Health, 129(1), 29-36.

3. Lee A., Cheng F., St Leger L. Evaluating Health Promoting Schools in Hong Kong: The Development of a Framework. Health Promotion International 2005; 20(2): 177-186.

4. Lee A. Hong Kong: Health Promoting School.In Whiteman CV and Aldringer C. Case Studies in Global School Health Promotion. Springer, New York, USA, 2009.

5. TordKjellstrom (Chair and Lead Writer). Our cities, our health, our future: Acting on social determinants for health equity in urban settings. Report of the Knowledge Network on Urban Settings, WHO Commission on Social Determinants of Health. WHO Centre for Health Development, Kobe, Japan – 2007 https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/default-source/documents/social-determinants-of-health/urban-settings-knowledge-network-final-report-2007.pdf

6. Nam EW, Moon J, Lee A. Evaluation of Healthy City Project Using SPIRIT Checklist: Wonju City Case. Journal of Korean Society for Health Education and Promotion 2010; 27(5): 15-25.

7. WHO. Regional Guidelines for developing a Healthy Cities Project. WHO Regional Office for the Western Pacific, 2000.

8. Lee A. Synergistic Effect of Joining Up Different Healthy Settings to Improve Population Health. Key speech for the session with full paper: The settings approach moves toward the future. The 3rd Global Conference of the Alliance for Healthy Cities. Ichikawa, Japan 24-26 October 2008.
courses.recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Health Communication

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description: This module will discuss various communication theories and their application in health promotion message design.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Demonstrate and work with in-depth theoretical knowledge from the area of health communication and critically analyse, evaluate and synthesise concepts, strategies, and cases from various disciplines, such as, communication, public health, psychology, sociology, and so on, to generate ideas for effective health communication

2. Apply knowledge and skills in developing and creating health communication campaigns; exercise appropriate judgement in the effects of various media and/or user-generated content on public beliefs about health issues and evaluate the effectiveness of health communication interventions;

3. Participate constructively in group discussions and make formal and informal presentations to specialised and non-specialised audiences on the objectives, strategies, and outcomes of the health communication campaigns conceived in class as part of a group project; use multi-media skills in creating and presenting the campaigns
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Health Communication
2. Channels and forms of Health Communication

3. Major Level 1 – Intrapersonal Health Communication
4. Major Level 2 – Interpersonal Health Communication
5. Major Level 3 – Group Health Communication

6. Major Level 4 –Public Health Communication
7. Major Level 5 – Mass Mediated Health Communication

8. Approaches to Health Communication
9. Barriers to Health Communication
10. Health Communication Campaign

3. Glanz, K., Rimer, B. K., & Viswanath, K. (Eds.). Health Behavior and Health Education: Theory, Research, and Practice. 5th edition. John Wiley & Sons, 2015.

courses.title: Research Methods in Community Health
courses.description: This module will focus on using mixed research methodology (quantitative, qualitative) to study community health practice. Students will learn how to develop appropriate tools for studying the desired health topic and translating the evidence into practice.

6. Preparation of quantitative data for coding and analysis I

9. Qualitative research: Observation studies
10. Qualitative research: Unstructured interview and focus groups
11. Data analysis for qualitative research

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Social Marketing Methods

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description:
Physical inactivity, unhealthy diet, smoking, people nowadays are often living an unhealthy lifestyle. Education and the rule of law have been used in attempts to change people’s behaviour with limited success. Social marketing is a systematic planning process that utilizes commercial marketing techniques to change people’s behaviour and achieve social good. The primary difference between social and commercial marketing is that the ultimate goal for commercial marketing is financial gain, whereas for social marketing, it is societal gain.

This course will focus on the social marketing planning process, which includes scoping, target and behaviour selection, understanding of facilitators and barriers, and design of social marketing campaigns.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PHPC3026
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to social marketing

2. Segmentation

3. Understand the priority segment

4. Describe the priority segment

5. Competition

6. Positioning

7. Presentation 1: Define the right problem to solve

8. Marketing mix I: Product

9. Marketing mix II: Price

10. Marketing mix III: Place

11. Marketing mix IV: Promotion

12. Finding the right mix

13. Presentation 2: Demonstrate a viable solution

Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.

Lee NR and Kotler P. Social marketing: Behavior Change for Social Good. 6th edition. Sage. 2020

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Community-Based Rehabilitation and Self-Care Management
courses.description: Although health advice and/or education is routinely given in day to day consultation with health professionals, more intensive self-management programmes should be designed for better control of chronic illnesses. Care in community is way forward for sustainable development of health care system. Patients including their caregivers need to be better equipped to maintain their functional capacity at optimal level. Students will learn the fundamental principles and concepts of community based rehabilitation by improving the health status of people with chronic visceral disability so they would live independently as far as possible. Students will also learn the skills to empower patients and families in self-management of chronic illness in community setting, and improving their health conditions.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overall view of chronic care model and community-based rehabilitation; Why is it important?

2. Dissecting out the essential components for successful patient self-management and community-based rehabilitation programmes

3. Self-Care behaviours for effective control for diabetes mellitus, hypertension, Lipid disorders

4. How would patients and their family members help themselves in Cardiac rehabilitation and pulmonary rehabilitation?

5. How would children with asthma maximize their functional capacity?

6. Would patients and their families help themselves with their mental health problem?

7. Will stroke patients be always home-bound? How would patients and carers maintain their cognitive functions?

8. a. Care for terminal illnesses?

b. What is District Health System?

9. Revisit the concept of community health practice
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.

Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings:
1. Lee A. Lecture Notes on Patient self-management and Community Based Rehabilitation. Centre for Health Education and Health Promotion, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, 2018 (website will be given for downloading)

2. Fong K and Tong KW (eds). Community Care in Hong Kong: Current Practices, Practice-Research Studies, and Future Directions. City University Press, 2014.

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Health Promotion Planning and Evaluation

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description: This course aims to provide a practical introduction to health promotion project planning. Successful health promotion project requires careful planning in order to increase project effectiveness and efficiency. Great health promotion project also takes into account the impact of project design on long-term generalizability and sustainability. This course will guide students through the process of planning a health promotion project, including developing project goals and objectives, choosing suitable intervention strategies, designing monitoring and evaluation methods, budgeting and timetabling.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: CHPR3008
Not for students who have taken PHPC2016 or 3026
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. Reiterate the process to develop a health intervention using the Intervention Mapping Approach

2. Describe real-world examples of how Intervention Mapping was used in different countries around the world

3. Draft a health promotion proposal
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course introduction; Planning health promotion interventions

2. Assessing community needs and assets; Tutorial 1: Group project introduction

3. Determination of program outcomes and performance objectives

4. Theory-based intervention

5. Tutorial 2: Logic of change for group project

6. Health promotion program design

7. Theory-based intervention; Tutorial 3: Intervention design for group project

8. Health promotion program production and implementation

9. Tutorial 4: Program material production for group project

10. Program monitoring and evaluation

11. Final presentation of health promotion project

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Food Security : Global and Local Perspectives
courses.description: Despite the advancement in economic development and food technology, there are people living without the basic supply of sufficient and clean foods require for their physiological well-being. The World Food Summit of 1996 defined food security as existing “when all people, at all times, have physical and economic access to sufficient, safe and nutritious food to meet their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life”. This course introduces the factors affecting the sustainability of the contemporary food systems at both global and local perspectives. Areas including natural and manmade disasters, technological advancement, economic drive, political stability, as well as socio-cultural influences will be analyzed critically as insights to tackle the challenge of future food crisis. The concept of food safety will be introduced as a sub-topic of food security.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Understand in detail the definition and scope of food security
2. Apply the understanding of food security to the analysis of global and local situations of food and nutrition supply
3. Realise the global effort in improving food insecurity and the promotion of food sufficiency for vulnerable populations in the local perspective
4. Understand the role and importance of food safety to human’s health and the steps of its protection mechanisms
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction to food security and food safety
- Food system in the 21st century
- Factors influencing the food system

- Impact of food security on human health
- Food security in Hong Kong and China
- Global efforts to achieve food security
- Guest speech: Food security in developing countries – the case in Vietnam
- Chit-chat with Oxfam Hong Kong food insecurity among low-income population

- Ensuring food safety to promote food security
- Food borne illnesses and human health
- Food safety control from production to consumption

- Food laws and regulations

- Challenges to a safe food system in Hong Kong: Impact of food supply from China
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings:
1. World food security: a history since 1945 / D. John Shaw

2. The State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World

3. Food safety: the science of keeping food safe / Ian C. Shaw

4. The food system a guide / Geoff Tansey & Tony Worsley

5. Food security and global environmental change / edited by John Ingram, Polly Ericksen, and Diana Liverman

6. Global food security: emerging issues and economic implication / Munir A. Hanjra

7. Food economics: industry and markets / Munir A. Hanjra

8. Food Security and farm land protection in China / Mao Yushi, Zhao Nong, Yang Xiaojing

9. Public health nutrition / edited on behalf of the Nutrition Society

10. The politics of land and food scarcity / Paolo De Castro

11. Hygiene in food processing: principles and practice / edited by H.L.M. Lelieveld, J.T. Holah and D. Napper

12. Food & drink: good manufacturing practice: a guide to its responsible management

13. HACCP / Sara Mortimore and Carol Wallace; compiling editor, Christos Cassianos

14. The ISO 9000 quality system: applications in food and technology

15. Food hygiene, microbiology and HACCP / S.J. Forsythe and P.R. Hayes

16. Food safety in China: a comprehensive review / Linhai Wu, Dian Zhu
courses.recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Mental Health as a Public Health Issue
courses.description: The course aims to enhance students’ knowledge on mental health and its determinants in public health and psychological perspectives. Major components of the course include 1) the epidemiology of mental health problems; 2) relationships among sociocultural factors, interpersonal resources, individual characteristics, and mental health; 3) mental health issues after adverse life events; 4) concepts and theories related to mental health promotion in the community; and 5) community health services and interventions to improve mental health.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. Understand the relationships among sociocultural factors, interpersonal resources, individual characteristics, and people’s mental health

2. Apply basic concepts in public health and psychological theories to understand the determinants of people’s mental health

3. Demonstrate understanding on mental health issues among urban people, at-risk populations, and people with negative life experience.

4. Familiarize themselves with current interventions and community services to improve people’s mental health.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction of the course, Epidemiology of common mental health problems

2. Individual factors as determinants of mental health

3. Sociocultural factors as determinants of mental health

4. Stress, coping, and mental health

5. Health behaviours and mental health

6. Addiction as a mental health issue

7. Mental health issues after negative life events

8. Psychological adjustment to chronic illnesses

9. Mental health among minority and at-risk populations

10. Positive psychology and, mental health

11. Disclosure and mental health

12. Community mental health services and interventions
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings: To be advised by the course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Practicum in Community Health Practice I
courses.description: This module provides the opportunity to practice the theories and skills learned in the programme. Students will explore the mission, vision and values of their placement site and the health needs of their serving communities. This module will prepare the students for their next field placement (CHPR4902).
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Apply knowledge and skills learned from taught courses as they participate as a working member of a community organization;

2. Assist in the design, execution and/or evaluation of health promotion or health service activities of relevant health organizations.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The first module of the two-part practicum begins with a briefing which focus on advising students about things they need to be mindful of prior to being engaged in the field.

2. Each student will be asked to select from a list of collaborating health promotion agencies as their practicum setting. These agencies include (but are not limited to) those that regularly employ individuals with a health promotion background, such as health education centres, non-profit health advocacy groups, hospitals/clinics, worksite wellness centres, and special population groups.

3. Prior to the engagement of practicum, each student must discuss his or her potential role and responsibilities with the assigned agency supervisor within two course terms (including CHPR4902) based on the major needs of the agency. The student’s involvement in a meaningful contributing role is strongly encouraged. Upon the end of this discussion, both parties will be asked to complete and sign an official form detailing the expectations on the students and the goals/objectives of their involvement.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by the course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

courses.subject: CHPR
courses.title: Practicum in Community Health Practice II
courses.description: This module is a continuation of CHPR4901 and will provide opportunities for experiential learning for students in community settings related to health promotion or health service. This experience is designed to place the students into a real work setting and be part of a team with other community health workers and provide opportunities for the students to apply their acquired knowledge and skills as they participate in health promotion or health services activities of designated community organizations.
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.course_syllabus: Student involvement in any activities or projects for this module should consist of no less than a total of 220 hours before the end of the term, the distribution of which is up to the discretion between the student, agency supervisor, and campus supervisor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions. Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.
